awd_titl_txt: Analyzing the Effects of Spatial Autocorrelation in Geospatial Databases
awd_abstract_narration:
NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION
GEOGRAPHY SPATIAL SCIENCES (GSS) PROGRAM

ABSTRACT

This research project will provide a better understanding of the spatial patterns of natural resources by analyzing the potential effects of spatial autocorrelation on the modeling and analyses of geospatial data.  The investigators will provide new insights for improving geospatial modeling procedures by quantifying the influences of spatial autocorrelation on a wide range of environmental predictor-response variables.  By analyzing and modeling multiple natural resources as they relate to a range of environmental factors across different ecosystems, the investigators will identify the interdependent relationships among soil, water, biodiversity, and environmental factors at multiple scales.  Project findings will inform government agencies and policy makers by providing new information and approaches for improved prediction and management for high-demand but scarce natural resources.  Outcomes from this spatial methodological framework will be useful in examining other ecological systems globally and potentially will serve as a springboard for establishing platforms for comprehensive management recommendations across diverse ecosystems.

In order to model and predict spatial phenomena, spatial scientists rely on multiple geocoded data sets that contain information about physical and biological resources.  Because of the interdependency among biophysical variables however, it is challenging to determine the relationships among the various the spatial processes and the predictor-response variables associated such phenomena.  The investigators will focus their analyses on the potential effects of spatial autocorrelation on the modeling and interpretation of the distribution of natural resources across landscapes.  They will analyze multiple global spatial data sets representing a variety of geographic and biophysical gradients, and they will develop a framework to better understand the different yet related geographic phenomena at multiple scales.  Spatial eigenvector mapping and environmental modeling will be used to analyze the complex relationships among predictor and response variables. The quantification of the influences of spatial autocorrelation will be catalytic for the understanding of potential networks and spatial processes across a broad spectrum of natural resources and geographic phenomena.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative research focused on the implications of the presence and effect of spatial autocorrelation (SAC) in physical geographical phenomena. The original aims of this project were to (1) identify the relationship between soil properties and landform parameters using non-spatial and spatial regression modeling and analysis, (2) identify the relationship between water quality variables and landscape factors using non-spatial and spatial regression modeling and analysis across different spatial and temporal scales, (3) identify the relationship between species diversity and environmental factors using non-spatial and spatial regression modeling and analysis, (4) understand the structure of spatial processes in physical geography and identify an appropriate specification of spatial weights for physical geographical phenomena, and finally (5) examine improvements of model performances with a model specification in which SAC is appropriately accounted for.

The project was conceived and conducted by three geographers with different subject specialties - biogeomorphology, hydroclimatology, and spatial statistics. The Principle investigators (PIs) enthusiastically trained three graduate students (one MS student and two PhD students), both in-person and online. Together with each PI's individual meetings with graduate students, the whole team members met regularly to exchange project progress online, offering cross-fertilization opportunities for all. For example, The PIs collectively helped the students to learn the theoretical background in physical geography and spatial statistical skills. These research endeavors produced 14 conference presentations, 3 invited presentations, and 9 peer-reviewed journal articles. There also were one MA thesis and one Ph.D. dissertation completed.

Overall, we achieved all objectives of the project successfully at varying degrees. In particular, regardless of the data types tested, we confirmed that the incorporation of SAC in spatial modeling procedures generally improved the outcomes through decreases in, for example, the level of residual SAC and Akaike Information Criteria (AIC). The degree of improvement correlated positively with the level of SAC inherent, especially in the dependent variables. That is, strongly autocorrelated dependent variables underwent greater decreases in residual SAC and AIC than those variables with weaker SAC. The results imply that spatial modeling outcomes are sensitive to and potentially predictable by the level of SAC possessed by dependent variables. Therefore, the degree of SAC present in the soil, water quality, or biodiversity variable can serve as a direct indicator of how much improvement a non-spatial OLS will experience if that SAC is properly accounted for. Additionally, we developed a novel configuration of a spatial weights matrix for a stream network system to better understand the relationship between landscape variables and water quality. The spatially-weighted network distance algorithm better explains how various landscape factors are associated with water quality at different scales.

To conclude, we propose that this collaborative research has opened a new possibility that geographers and environmental scientists can explain which spatial processes are associated with different yet related natural phenomena at different scales. As such, this project, which stresses the importance of considering spatial autocorrelation and distance in landscape spatial modeling, offers useful information for natural resource managers who are interested in improving the quality of the environment with limited field observations.
